headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Doris and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Q3 Fiscal Year '16 EA Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] .I would now turn the call over to our host, Mr.
componenttext:
Good afternoon. My name is Doris and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Q3 Fiscal Year '16 EA Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] .
I would now turn the call over to our host, Mr. Chris Evenden, Vice President of Investor Relations. Sir, please go ahead.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Doris. Welcome to EA's Fiscal 2016 Third Quarter Earnings Call. With me on the call today are Andrew Wilson, our CEO; Blake Jorgensen, our CFO; and Peter Moore, our COO, will be joining us for the Q&A portion of the call.Please note that our
componenttext:
Thank you, Doris. Welcome to EA's Fiscal 2016 Third Quarter Earnings Call. With me on the call today are Andrew Wilson, our CEO; Blake Jorgensen, our CFO; and Peter Moore, our COO, will be joining us for the Q&A portion of the call.
Please note that our SEC filings and our earnings reserve available at ir.ea.com. In addition, we have posted earnings slides to accompany our prepared remarks. 
Lastly, after the call, we will post our prepared remarks, an audio replay of this call and the transcript. 
A couple of events regarding upcoming events. We're holding our Investor Day on Tuesday, May 17, at our Redwood City headquarters. This will be great opportunity for members of the financial community to hear from our senior management team and meet with them in an informal environment. In addition, Blake will be presenting at the Morgan Stanley conference on Tuesday, March 1[ph], and our Q4 and year-end earnings call is scheduled for Tuesday, May 10.
This presentation and our comments include forward-looking statements regarding future events and the future financial performance of the company. Actual events and results may differ materially from our expectations. We refer you to our most recent Form 10-Q for a discussion of risks that could cause actual results to differ materially from those discussed today. Electronic Arts makes these statements as of today, January 28, 2016, and disclaims any duty to update them.
During this call, unless otherwise stated, the financial metrics will be presented on a non-GAAP basis. Our earnings release and the earnings slides provide a reconciliation of our GAAP to non-GAAP measures. These non-GAAP measures are not intended to be considered in isolation from, as a substitute for, or superior to, our GAAP results. We encourage investors to consider all measures before making an investment decision. All comparisons made in the course of this call are against the same period in the prior year unless otherwise stated.
Now I'll turn the call over to Andrew.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chris. Q3 FY '16 was a great quarter for Electronic Arts. Across all key platforms, we delivered amazing new experiences for our players and large services that enabled them to play more of the games mean up. Non-GAAP revenue and earnings wer
componenttext:
Thank you, Chris. 
Q3 FY '16 was a great quarter for Electronic Arts. Across all key platforms, we delivered amazing new experiences for our players and large services that enabled them to play more of the games mean up. Non-GAAP revenue and earnings were above our guidance for the quarter, and we are raising our full year non-GAAP guidance as we continue our strong momentum in the final quarter of the year. 
I'll highlight from the holiday quarter, capture how players are engaging across the increasing breadth and depth of games and services from Electronic Arts. Q3 was a breakthrough quarter for our partnership with Disney and Lucasfilm on the Star Wars franchise. With Star Wars Battlefront, our team [indiscernible] delivered a game with amazing visual fidelity, unmatched authenticity and true Star Wars action fantasies that are fun for all ages. It became the largest launch ever for Star Wars game and exceeded our guidance for the full year. 
The journey's just beginning for Battlefront fans. Earlier this week, we announced our first free content update as well as the 4 expansion packs that come for Star Wars Battlefront, and there are many new experiences in development for every player in the growing community. Star Wars fans are deeply engaged in their experiences in mobile and PC as well. On mobile, Star Wars Galaxies quickly built a strong player base after it launched in November, reaching a Top 5 Most Downloaded iOS games in more than 130 countries. 
On PC, our Star Wars community has grown to the highest subscriber level in nearly 3 years, driven by the larger digital expansion, [indiscernible] empire. More break content is on the way for placing each of these experiences, as well as new Star Wars titles for multiple platforms in development across the company. 
Continuing the mobile momentum, Madden NFL Mobile is a cultural hit that topped the U.S. App Store charts over the holiday period. Player engagement is thriving with monthly active players up nearly 50% year-over-year and our live events driving 2.5x more games played over the previous year. Madden NFL Mobile continues to illustrate the opportunity for sports games on mobile devices. Just as we've demonstrated on other platforms, great sports experiences will ignite fans unbridled commitment to the teams and sports they love, driving deeper engagement over time. 
Building on the success of Madden NFL Mobile, we are excited to bring more compelling EA SPORTS experiences to our players on mobile devices. 
As a top game publisher on PlayStation 4 and Xbox One consoles in the Western World for calendar year 2015, EA continues to captivate players with some of the world's biggest and most popular franchises. Madden NFL 16 was the #1 sports title in the U.S. and FIFA 16 was the #1 title across all genres in Europe for calendar year 2015. Player engagement continues to grow across our entire year EA SPORTS portfolio with monthly active players growing more than 10% year-over-year in the third quarter. 
And the return of Need for Speed delivered for racing car and car culture enthusiasts with more than twice as many monthly active players in Q3 compared to our previous games. 
Live services are at the core of how we help our players connect with each other and stay engaged to their favorite games longer. Our EA SPORTS Ultimate Team services continue to engage more fans year-over-year in Q3, driven in part by new experiences like draft in FIFA 16 and draft champions in Madden NFL 16. We also continued to see long-term engagement across Battlefield 4 and Battlefield Hardline. 
In Q3, our players worked more than 150 million hours of Battlefield gameplay. 
Our subscription programs represent a key opportunity to connect players to even more great games. EA Access continues to grow on subscribers, and more than 60% of those players have used EA Access to try a game they haven't previously played. Based on the success of EA Access, we've just launched Origin Access, expanding our subscription programs to the PC platform. Early reaction for Origin Access has been equally positive, and it's clear that our global player base sees value in this innovative approach to playing more games. 
EA Access and Origin Access are great examples of how EA's working its players with one of the more compelling challenges in entertainment today. In a world that sees more competition ever for our players time, we are focused on delivering services that reduce friction and barriers to discovery, allowing them to maximize the time they have to play their favorite games or try something new. Through deeper relationships, we can help more players connect vibrant communities, access more games and content and engage in experiences that are meaningful, personal and fun. 
In Q3, we captivated players with stunning new experiences and more great content for the games and services they love. 
Now I'll hand the call over to Blake for a deeper look at our financials.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andrew. EA's non-GAAP net revenue was $1.803 billion, which was $28 million above our guidance. The quarter's revenue was 26% higher than the prior years, primarily driven by Star Wars Battlefront and Need for Speed, but also by growth across th
componenttext:
Thanks, Andrew. 
EA's non-GAAP net revenue was $1.803 billion, which was $28 million above our guidance. The quarter's revenue was 26% higher than the prior years, primarily driven by Star Wars Battlefront and Need for Speed, but also by growth across the breadth of our platform, including Ultimate Team, mobile and catalog. 
Star Wars Battlefront surpassed our full year fiscal guidance of 13 million units, which includes over 1 million units bundled with consoles. On a constant currency basis, revenue would have been up 35% year-over-year. 
Our non-GAAP Digital net revenue for the quarter increased 16% year-over-year to a record $807 million, 45% of this quarter's revenue. It was also a record for the trailing 12-month period, which was up 11% to $2.42 billion. 
Breaking down our digital revenue into its key component highlights the performance of each of these businesses this quarter. Extra content and free-to-play contributed $360 million, up 15% over the prior year. The principal driver of the growth was Ultimate Team. In particular, seasonal Ultimate Team showed strong growth, up 8% year-on-year or 18% year-over-year at constant currency. Madden Ultimate Team and the Hockey Ultimate Team also grew. 
Finally FIFA Online 3, our PC free-to-play title in China and Korea, continues to perform well and is tracking to our expectations. 
Mobile generated $162 million in the quarter, up 17% year-on-year. Our big launch during the quarter was Star Wars Galaxy of Heroes and it has performed extremely well, a great start for our newest live service. In addition, Madden NFL Mobile was in the top 3 grossing apps in the U.S. on the iOS App Store through the important Christmas period and peaked at #1 on Christmas day. 
To join our broad portfolio of strong portfolio revenue-generating titles, which also include SimCity BuildIt, Sims FreePlay, the Simpsons Tapped Out, Need for Speed No Limits and Real Racing 3. 
Full game PC and console downloads generated $195 million, up 39% over the prior year, driven by Star Wars Battlefront and offset by FX. Star Wars Battlefront was our largest digital launch ever, although it did lean more towards physical copies over the full quarter as holiday giftgiving became the dominant driver purchases. Note that the revenue from the large number of copies sold bundled with consoles is counted as physical revenue even though they are distributed as digital codes. And this revenue would be recognized in our fourth quarter. 
Subscriptions, advertising and other digital total revenue contributed $90 million, down 10% from last year due to the natural decline in the recognition of Battlefield 4 Premium revenue. However, EA Access is delivering strong sustained growth and we launched a similar PC subscription Origin Access in January. Our most recent update to Star Wars: The Old Republic has fueled subscriber growth with its rich content and deep storytelling. 
Moving on to gross margin. Our non-GAAP gross margin for the quarter was 70.4%, down from last year's 72.8% and 110 basis points below our guidance. The decrease from last year was driven largely by mix with Dragon acquisition last year compared to the royalty bearing Star Wars Battlefront this year. We have factored into the guidance our expectations at Star Wars Battlefront would be a strong giftgiving titles, but it's skewed even more physical than we had anticipated. 
The other significant driver of the margin shortfall versus guidance this quarter was also a positive, the strong performance of our royalty bearing console and mobile games, which triggered greater royalty expenses than expected. 
Our non-GAAP operating expenses for the quarter were $511 million, down $10 million year-on-year driven by FX. At constant currency, OpEx would have been $22 million up, driven chiefly by increasing investment in marketing to support the bigger launches this quarter compared to a year ago. The improvement on guidance was driven by phasing and continued cost control. 
The resulting non-GAAP diluted EPS was $1.83 per share, which is $0.08 better than guidance due to our strong public performance and continued cost management. 
Our cash and short-term investments in the end of the quarter was $3.23 billion or approximately $10.42 per share. 51% of this cash and short-term investment balance is held onshore. This is down from 57% held onshore last quarter, the difference being partly driven by stock repurchases and settlements of early redemptions of our convertible notes. 
During Q3, we settled $95 million in early conversions of our convertible notes. Through December 31, we redeemed $293 million of the $633 million total. And as of yesterday, we received notices for an additional $177 million to settle in Q4. We've updated the dilution table on our website accordingly. 
We also repurchased 1.8 million shares at a cost of $126 million, leaving $672 million in our 2-year $1 billion buyback program we began in May 2015. The current rate of repurchase keeps us on track to complete the full $1 billion in that time. 
Net cash provided by operating activities for the quarter was $889 million. This is, by a significant margin, the largest quarterly operating cash flow every generated in the history of the company and $207 million more than last year. On a trailing 12-month basis, operating cash flow was 100 -- or $1.025 billion. 
Turning to guidance, we expect our fourth quarter non-GAAP net revenue to be $875 million, $21 million lower than last year's. The decline is driven by the absence of last year's Battlefield Hardline, offset by Plants vs. Zombies Garden Worker 2, UFC 2 and Unravel this year. Sales of our new titles have been strong and we believe continued weakness in the game sale for last generation consoles will continue to be a headwind. 
Finally, we expect FX to impact sales by around $40 million in the quarter compared to last year. Non-GAAP gross margin is forecasted to be 76%, 60 basis points above last year's. We expect our Q4 non-GAAP operating expense to be $500 million, down slightly year-on-year driven by FX and partially offset by increased investment in R&D. This results in a non-GAAP diluted EPS of $0.40 per share as calm $0.39 last year. 
Our Q4 GAAP net revenue is expected to be $1.275 billion as compared to $1.185 billion in the prior year. GAAP earnings per diluted share is expected to be $1.46 as compared to $1.19 in the prior year. 
I would like to highlight one item related to income taxes that is not included in this GAAP guidance. As a result of our GAAP earnings in the U.S. over the last 2 years, in the fourth quarter, we may record a material income tax credit due to a reversal of a significant portion of the valuation allowance we have against our U.S. deferred tax assets. This would significantly increase our GAAP earnings per share but would have no effect on non-GAAP earnings for our cash flow. 
Our Q4 outlook would result in a full year non-GAAP revenue of $4.517 billion and non-GAAP EPS of $3.04 per share. This is an increase from our previous guidance of $4.5 billion and $0.03 per share, respectively. Our anticipated operating margin remains at 28%. 
Our Q4 GAAP guidance implies full year GAAP revenue of $4.363 billion and fully diluted GAAP EPS of $2.23 per share. Comparing cash flow for the full fiscal year, we are maintaining our operating cash flow guidance at approximately $1.2 billion and the free cash flow guidance of at least $1.1 billion as capital expenditure is tracking below our $100 million estimate for the year. 
Despite the considerable uncertainty around the state of the world economy, we remain confident in our ability to continue to grow earnings and cash flow. 
Q3 was another strong quarter for Electronic Arts and a new high watermark for cash generation. Our strategy is to assemble a broad portfolio of games, leveraging both wholly-owned and live [indiscernible] IT. This builds a deep catalog that sell 3 years and provide the right balance of innovation and predictability for long-term earnings and cash flow growth. 
Now I'll turn the call back to Andrew.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Blake. FY '16 has been a groundbreaking year so far for Electronic Arts on so many fronts. Starting new games, dynamic services and new opportunities to connect and celebrate the passion for play we share with our payers. Amazing game experience
componenttext:
Thanks, Blake. 
FY '16 has been a groundbreaking year so far for Electronic Arts on so many fronts. Starting new games, dynamic services and new opportunities to connect and celebrate the passion for play we share with our payers. Amazing game experiences begin with creativity and innovation, and we are focused on delivering out to players wherever they want to play. Leveraging our powerful Star Wars IP, we're now connected with players in live services across 3 games on 3 platforms and 3 business models. 
In Star Wars Battlefront and HD console experience, we are building a major franchise with passionate fans. In Star Wars Galaxy of Heroes, a free-to-download game on mobile, we have a successful new live service. And in Star Wars : The Old Republic, we've demonstrated the longevity of an experience as great IP and content that continues to delivering enjoyment for our player. 
In Q4, we will go live with 3 new titles that further reflect the creativity, innovation and variety in our experiences today. Unravel launches on February 9, bringing Yani's journey to life in the charming and beautiful world crafted by our partners at Colbert Interactive. 
On February 23, plants vs. Zombies Garden Warfare 2 goes live, with all of its over-the-top action and hilarious characters ready for new and existing fans of this beloved franchise. 
Then on March 15, we return the octagon with EA SPORTS UFC 2 set to debut featuring new fighters, new physics and new modes for fight fans around the world. 
Looking ahead to FY '17, we will introduce breakthrough games from some of our biggest and most popular franchises. In Q1, we'll begin with a creative and innovative Mirrors Age catalysts from [indiscernible], launching in May. A great line of EA SPORTS title are in development for next year and we look forward to sharing more about these new experiences in the months ahead. 
An all new battlefield game from DICE will arrive in time for the holidays. We're excited to have a new time full of experience coming from our friends at Respawn and, of course, Mass Effect: Andromeda from the team at BioWare will launch later in the fiscal year. 
Players in our live services will continue to experience engaging new content, expansions and update and we'll have more in mobile titles as well. 
Competition runs deep in the DNA of Electronic Arts and we're thrilled to share the passion with our players through our new competitive Gaming division, led by Peter Moore. For years, we've experienced the energy of competitive gaming through events and tournaments for EA SPORTS and Battlefield communities. 
As the global gaming audience grows, we are working to deliver a best-in-class program of competition that are accessible, engaging and entertaining at all levels, celebrating the talent and skill of our players. We are already underway with players competing in the Madden NFL live challenge that culminates with the finals here in San Francisco during Super Bowl week. We're accepted to have Peter and the team on more plans as we get into FY '17. 
From our new titles to our lives services, new programs like Origin Access to new frontiers, like competitive gaming, Electronic Arts continues to focus on putting our players first in everything we do. Games delivered on a fundamental human need for entertainment. And for each of us, that means something unique and personal. And you can connect to compete, to explore, to improve, to challenge, to share. We are focused on understanding these needs for every player, building strong relationships so we can fulfill them at the right place and time and unlocking the full potential of play through amazing new experiences. 
The commitment we have to our players continues to transform Electronic Arts and galvanize that to deliver disruptive and innovative new ways to play. 
Now Blake, Peter and I are here for your questions.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from the line of Chris Merwin.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from the line of Chris Merwin.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just had one digital downloads. This past holiday season, I think, we've seen some industry data points that show that AAA launches reflected higher in terms of digital, but digital downloads are a bit lighter than we would expected for you all. Blake,
componenttext: I just had one digital downloads. This past holiday season, I think, we've seen some industry data points that show that AAA launches reflected higher in terms of digital, but digital downloads are a bit lighter than we would expected for you all. Blake, you commented that Star Wars was a much more heavily gifted title during the holiday season, which I think makes a lot of sense given the younger audience. So next year when you release Battlefield 5, are you expecting to see more of an inflection in digital downloads? And is this 1 point of gross margin expansion per year still the right target going forward? Second quick question, if you won't mind telling us how engagement has been trending for Star Wars relative to maybe Battlefield 4? And when we think about that the DLC which will be selling for that title, is it fair to assume that the attach rate would be comparable to that of Battlefield 4?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me start with the full game download and Andrew might want to talk a little bit about the Battlefield -- Battlefront engagement. First, I'll remind you that full game downloads generated 195 million, up 39% year-over-year. So while we might not
componenttext: Sure. Let me start with the full game download and Andrew might want to talk a little bit about the Battlefield -- Battlefront engagement. First, I'll remind you that full game downloads generated 195 million, up 39% year-over-year. So while we might not have done as many on Star Wars as we thought we could do, that's still a big number and many of our other titles are obviously skewing heavily towards full downloads since you couldn't have gotten the number of that size in the quarter without that. We were surprised that more giftgiving was done with Star Wars, which obviously, impacted the digital downloads. And my guess is, is that, that will be less so next year because Battlefront tends to skew less towards giftgiving and more towards PC, that's a very hard-core PC audience to the Battlefield audience and they tend to obviously more physical or digital downloads and physical. So we should tend to see a return to that gross margin guidance that we've talked about in the past. We'll obviously, give you a detailed gross margin guidance in May for the full year. But based on what we know about the Star Wars title in giftgiving, we would be very surprised if we didn't shift the back to improvements in gross margin that we saw.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: On engagement, engagement has been strong, it's been a great to play across multiple generations. So the audience is much wider than a traditional Battlefield audience, which is great for us while introducing new people to Electronic Arts and to games and
componenttext: On engagement, engagement has been strong, it's been a great to play across multiple generations. So the audience is much wider than a traditional Battlefield audience, which is great for us while introducing new people to Electronic Arts and to games and to the first person shooting genre. We have just announced our first batch of free content and our 4 maps that will form part of the premium service. And we expect strong engagement with that going forward.

componenttext: This is Chris on for Stephen. 2 quick questions from our end. You said you sold 13 million units of Battlefront and 1 million of them are bundled. Wondering if you guys are seeing any excess inventory in the channel? And then can you touch a bit on what you've seen so far with Origins Access to the subscribers, how same propensity to try new games, maybe new genres that they've not played before just like EA Access?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on the Origin Access piece that we just rolled it out, so it's very early days and hard to get any data yet. So more to come on that. But we obviously, we're very excited about what we've been seeing in EA Access, and that was part of the reason we dec
componenttext: So on the Origin Access piece that we just rolled it out, so it's very early days and hard to get any data yet. So more to come on that. But we obviously, we're very excited about what we've been seeing in EA Access, and that was part of the reason we decided to roll out Origin Access as a different group of title because not all of our titles are PC titles. So we'll probably made some different dynamics between players, but we hope to see some more dynamics than we have seen in EA Access because it's exciting to see obviously people broaden their interest in more games than simply 1 franchise. On your first question, can you go back and just repeat again what you were looking for there?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So you guys said, you've sold in 13 million units of Battlefront and 1 million of that was consistent in the bundles. Do you guys have any excess inventory in the channel?
componenttext: Yes. So you guys said, you've sold in 13 million units of Battlefront and 1 million of that was consistent in the bundles. Do you guys have any excess inventory in the channel?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. We're very comfortable with where the channel is. We actually had a very strong sellthrough during the quarter, as well as sell in. And there are some accounts obviously, that are replenishing in their -- as they get to their January time frame. And w
componenttext: No. We're very comfortable with where the channel is. We actually had a very strong sellthrough during the quarter, as well as sell in. And there are some accounts obviously, that are replenishing in their -- as they get to their January time frame. And we're very comfortable with where the channel inventory is there.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And this is Peter, as regards to competitive gaming obviously, we see a great opportunity going forward here. And I'll remind you and I know you know this that we've been doing this for a number of years, whether it's been involvement with FIFA with the F
componenttext: And this is Peter, as regards to competitive gaming obviously, we see a great opportunity going forward here. And I'll remind you and I know you know this that we've been doing this for a number of years, whether it's been involvement with FIFA with the FIFA interactive world cup. As was mentioned in the prepared remarks, we're looking forward to the finals of the Madden challenge series at the Madden bowl on [indiscernible] here in the Bay Area. But we also see this maybe a little bit differently than maybe some of our publishing brethren that are in the marketplace right now, and we see this as a tool and a platform to increase engagement. More and more session days with games is good for Electronic Arts, it's good for our players. We've taken a very player first view on this in which we're building community. It's clearly an entertainment medium. I think, there's a lot of excitement around of it and I can't think of anybody that's better served with the diversity of our portfolio when you think of our sports titles in particular. Take Madden as well as our Battlefield franchise that we've been able to build a meaningful business over the next couple of years.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Brian Pitz.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Brian Pitz.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Jay in for Brian. Just another question on Star Wars. So just wondering how much of the mix shift towards physical discs do you attribute to heavy promotional activity like GameStop's $40 sale? So just curious about how those kinds of retail promo
componenttext: This is Jay in for Brian. Just another question on Star Wars. So just wondering how much of the mix shift towards physical discs do you attribute to heavy promotional activity like GameStop's $40 sale? So just curious about how those kinds of retail promotions, how effective are they in terms of attracting new users? And just on the same subject, I know you take a 20% reserve on gross revenue for each unit shipped. I'm just curious if you could quantify the impact on your P&L and GameStop offers discounts that we saw, how is the impact -- how does this impact gross margin?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I'll [indiscernible] to the first discounting in general. This is a business for that in the holiday time frame between Black Friday and Christmas is traditionally done a lot of discounting. It's a way of driving volume, particularly when people a
componenttext: Yes. So I'll [indiscernible] to the first discounting in general. This is a business for that in the holiday time frame between Black Friday and Christmas is traditionally done a lot of discounting. It's a way of driving volume, particularly when people are now buying for the first time a new console. Often, they want to build up their software inventory pretty quickly and we find the discounting helps drive people into the engagement. We, obviously, share that view with the retailers and we help support the retailers in that each year with specific programs. And I think we've done that year-over-year and it really doesn't impact that. We're also doing discounting on the digital side as we try to keep it to a line, we don't want to have a disconnect between pricing in one area and pricing in another. So you'll tend to see us drive volumes through discounting and it's pretty consistent year in, year out. I would say this year, our programs were very similar to what you saw last year or similar to what we've seen with all of our other industry partners and titles that they may have had. There wasn't a lot of difference between years. On the sales reserve, we take the sales reserves upfront at the start of each quarter in anticipation of what our sell in is going to be. And we use those sells reserves during the quarter on a very formalized plan, that's to sell all of these sales get planned well in advance and we need to make sure that we have appropriate reserves in place to help pay for those over time. And so we'll be setting up sales reservers each quarter as we go in, and those tend not to impact margins or margins that we forecast because they're already built into the numbers.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then if I could, I believe Andrew mentioned that you're attracting a new type of demographic to Star Wars. I'm just wondering for any sort of color on that, what's the -- who are the new players? What does the demographic breakdown look like of that g
componenttext: And then if I could, I believe Andrew mentioned that you're attracting a new type of demographic to Star Wars. I'm just wondering for any sort of color on that, what's the -- who are the new players? What does the demographic breakdown look like of that game? And what types of new -- what's the new demographic your attracting to the EA tent?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I can't take that. So what we've seen is really there's 2 groups that come to the first title or come back to gaming. The first group is people quite frankly, of my generation or my vintage who have been gamers in the past have for whatever reason ki
componenttext: Yes, I can't take that. So what we've seen is really there's 2 groups that come to the first title or come back to gaming. The first group is people quite frankly, of my generation or my vintage who have been gamers in the past have for whatever reason kind of moved away from it, particularly moved away from core shooters because they've become very hard and complicated and quite frankly, brutal to play online. They have come back in light of the Star Wars IP and the commitment and passion they have around that their use. At the same time, they now have kids, who are gameplaying age, who may not have gotten to the first-person shooting universe yet because of the nature of the content inside some of those games. And so we're seeing fathers and sons play, we're seeing mothers and daughters play because of the broad appeal. And so the big groups that we've added is kind of a used demographic that's skews typically younger than we have seen before as well as an older demographic that we may have had interaction with some easy got, but may have lapsed up in recent years, particularly from first-person shooting universe. And we're looking now at how we continue to provide content and experiences that engage those 2 new groups so that we maintain relationships with  them over time.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Justin Post.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Justin Post.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This Ryan on for Justin. Wondering if you could talk about how demand's looking at early 4Q. And then maybe how much you expect that title to contribute, either digitally or physically or combined during the quarter? And then you highlighted some of the t
componenttext: This Ryan on for Justin. Wondering if you could talk about how demand's looking at early 4Q. And then maybe how much you expect that title to contribute, either digitally or physically or combined during the quarter? And then you highlighted some of the titles that you guys are working on, especially for next year. Wondering how you're thinking about spacing for all those titles or in Battlefield, Mass Effect, Time Fall and maybe Mirrors just in there as well? And then lastly, just going to the digital to mix shift, is it fair to say that really the digital mix shift away from downloads is onetime in nature and just really the specific Star Wars title? Or is there any reason for us to think that EA won't continue to see the benefit of the margin side from the industry going digitally and into 4Q and then into fiscal '17?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me start there. I don't think there's any indication that, that this mix shift is anything but a Star Wars Battlefront opportunity. Remember, the movie was out, all things Star Wars for the month of December and it was the perfect giftgiving oppo
componenttext: Yes, let me start there. I don't think there's any indication that, that this mix shift is anything but a Star Wars Battlefront opportunity. Remember, the movie was out, all things Star Wars for the month of December and it was the perfect giftgiving opportunity. And typically would gift someone who wants to have a package under a tree or at a gift pile somewhere versus a digital code and that was driver of the shift. We could see when we do the next Battlefront, we could see something like that but we have no idea on exact timing it for the sales in the industry and exactly how the buzz on Star Wars will be why that comes the next time around. So right now, I would say nothing would imply to us that the digital journey is slowing in any way. And in fact, we look at all of our non-Star Wars products, every one of them were up digitally in full game downloads and the digital engagement associated with them. When you look at all to ultimate teams statistics we gave you, that's a clear sign that people are playing and engaging longer and longer around the titles. In terms of guidance, guidance on Star Wars, we're not going to break out individual guidance. Obviously, we'll end up selling more than 13 million units since we've already gotten there. We did sell more in the third quarter, so we may ultimately sell less in the fourth quarter than we originally thought. But we'll clearly sell more overall and that's built into our guidance for the fourth quarter. I will remind people about fourth quarter though, don't forget that there's a continued FX headwind, headwind that we called out, that's $40 million of headwind. I'm not sure everyone's modeling that into their models. And we're not ignoring the fact that there's the economic headwinds out there around the world that haven't really impacted us, but we're being conservative when we give our guidance around watching that closely. In terms of next year's guidance, the title slate that we talked about are the core titles along with traditional sports titles. The one thing to note is Q1, the only title we have in Q1 is Mirror's Edge, plus all of our catalog business in live services business. Our core console title will be Mirror's Edge. And if you're doing -- we'll give you full year guidance in May when we sit down to do the next earnings call. But as you're starting to think about guidance for Q1 and next year, don't forget about the continued FX headwinds, which are impacting us, as well as in Q1 one specific item, remember that last year in Q1, we had a $30 million benefit, onetime benefit from FIFA Online 3 as we started that up and we had deferred revenue on into Q1. So that's a high profit revenue that came into Q1, a couple of basic things for your model but things to remember. But we're excited about the rest of the slate. You should assume that a Battlefield will come typically in the third quarter when we normally have it. We're not yet announcing when Titan Fall or Mass Effect Andromeda will come, but assume that's in the back half of the year as well because the second quarter is so dominated by our sports titles.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Okay. If I could have 1 last follow up, there's a nice pick up in mobile revenue. Do you guys happen to have updated MAU figure that you can share?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Arvind Bhatia.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Couple of questions. One, I know you guys touched on Madden NFL Mobile did really well this quarter. Wondering what are some of the learnings, Andrew, in particular that maybe could apply to FIFA Mobile and other titles specifically? And then wondering if
componenttext: Couple of questions. One, I know you guys touched on Madden NFL Mobile did really well this quarter. Wondering what are some of the learnings, Andrew, in particular that maybe could apply to FIFA Mobile and other titles specifically? And then wondering if you guys are willing to share the mix of full game physical downloads on some of the key titles during the quarter? And for any of you, I guess, just would love some thoughts on virtual reality and your efforts there currently?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, I'll take the Madden Mobile 1. As we think about all of our mobile games, we really think about them on 4 vectors. Discovery, how someone will find the title, whether that's through an App Store or through social representation. On boarding, how som
componenttext: Sure, I'll take the Madden Mobile 1. As we think about all of our mobile games, we really think about them on 4 vectors. Discovery, how someone will find the title, whether that's through an App Store or through social representation. On boarding, how someone will get into the title. The gameplay mechanic itself is actually what you do while you're playing the game and then how do we run the service that actually surrounds that game to make it new interesting, fun and dynamic and engaging on a moment-to-moment, day-to-day basis. As we look at what we've done with Madden NFL Mobile over the last couple of years, you'll have seen we've fundamentally overhauled all 4 of those vectors since we first launched Madden on mobile devices. We now believe we have landed in a place that has a game that is very social in nature, has a game that onboards new players in a broad demographic of players. We have a game mechanic that feels right for mobile devices, and our teams are delivering live events that tie to the passion that players have for the real world of the NFL and a very engaging for them on an ongoing basis but during the weekends games and the week leading up to the games. All of those opportunities present learning for us as we take these types of things to our sports games and mobile, and we expect to be able to do well in those areas.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Arvind, your second question was about trends in full game downloads, we continue to see the trending upwards, we see titles running anywhere between 20 and 30-plus percent. We've always seen FIFA skew lower because in Europe, many retailers use that as a
componenttext: Arvind, your second question was about trends in full game downloads, we continue to see the trending upwards, we see titles running anywhere between 20 and 30-plus percent. We've always seen FIFA skew lower because in Europe, many retailers use that as a leader to drive traffic into their stores and that tends to be a physical copy. But in the rest of our SPORTS portfolio, we tend to see strong digital full game. Really Star Wars was the only Gen4 title that indexed lower than the average because of the giftgiving issue. So we're very comfortable with the continuation of where that trend's going industry-wide.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then on VR?
componenttext: Got it. And then on VR?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry, the context of VR?
componenttext: Sorry, the context of VR?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wondering if your -- what your investments are currently? And how you're viewing sort of the opportunity this year and perhaps sort of the next couple of years, if you have any titles currently in development and any early thoughts there?
componenttext: Just wondering if your -- what your investments are currently? And how you're viewing sort of the opportunity this year and perhaps sort of the next couple of years, if you have any titles currently in development and any early thoughts there?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. And I'll echo what we've talked about on some previous calls which is we believe that VR is going to be an important part of our industry. We do believe it's a number of years out before it's a meaningful part of our industry. But right now, we're i
componenttext: Sure. And I'll echo what we've talked about on some previous calls which is we believe that VR is going to be an important part of our industry. We do believe it's a number of years out before it's a meaningful part of our industry. But right now, we're investing at a core engine level. We've talked about Frostbite as we move through single engine for the company and that team is working to ensure that they can output virtual reality experience regardless of device. And then we have a few key game teams around the company who are doing targeted experiments as it relates to very engaging virtual reality experiences in the context of particular genres. I would expect that we would start to surface some of those over the coming years. And that they would start to build them into more fully fledged experiences over time.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Mike Olson.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Mike Olson.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Do you had obviously, big launches of Star Wars in the quarter and no doubt that had some marketing and other expenses. And yet, the overall OpEx was basically down year-over-year, so the cost containment efforts continued to remain strong. How do you thi
componenttext: Do you had obviously, big launches of Star Wars in the quarter and no doubt that had some marketing and other expenses. And yet, the overall OpEx was basically down year-over-year, so the cost containment efforts continued to remain strong. How do you think about OpEx going forward with a lot of these incremental titles coming in fiscal '17? Is there a reason to think that OpEx will start to creep higher? Is that kind of a reasonable multi-year urn rate going forward where we're at this year?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think at the pure dollar OpEx has gotten  -- we've gotten the benefit this year of FX on our OpEx line because many of our studios are outside the U.S. So we have a large base obviously in Sweden, in Canada, in Romania, in Australia, in China. Many
componenttext: Yes. I think at the pure dollar OpEx has gotten  -- we've gotten the benefit this year of FX on our OpEx line because many of our studios are outside the U.S. So we have a large base obviously in Sweden, in Canada, in Romania, in Australia, in China. Many of those have obviously come in at lower dollar costs. We tried to report each quarter what the actual dollar cost are and you've seen some continued investment. Our goal is to try to keep R&D expenses around the 22% to 23% of revenue line, which means if our revenue is growing, we're clearly continuing to invest in R&D, we think that's very important for our future. You'll see marketing expenses bounce around, depending on the title and the quarter. So this quarter, our marketing expense were up in if you FX adjust them and that was driven by the fact that we had a fairly large part of this year that we didn't have last year's third quarter. This year's Star Wars, obviously last year our largest title was Battlefront Hardline in the fourth quarter. So you get some of the timing differences, but you will continue to see generally increases in OpEx with goal to try to target R&D around the 22% to 23%, we're trying to push marketing expenses down into 13% range and hold G&A in that 8% to 7% range, if possible. So that's [indiscernible] as a percentage of revenue and, hopefully, will continue to be reflected in the business going forward.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And one quick one, is there any detail you can given on the timing of the first monetized Star Wars expansion pack? Is that in the month of March? And if so, can you say it's earlier or late in the month?
componenttext: Okay. And one quick one, is there any detail you can given on the timing of the first monetized Star Wars expansion pack? Is that in the month of March? And if so, can you say it's earlier or late in the month?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I can't say much more than March. But I would assume that much of that revenue will probably fall in the first quarter versus the fourth quarter, but it's hard to see right now.
componenttext: I can't say much more than March. But I would assume that much of that revenue will probably fall in the first quarter versus the fourth quarter, but it's hard to see right now.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Next question from the line of [indiscernible].

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Ultimate Team, up 13% in the quarter. It seems like an impressive number given the comp. I think you guys had some pull forward recognized in the second quarter. So what is Ultimate Team up here to date? And can you comment on the expectations in Ultim
componenttext: So Ultimate Team, up 13% in the quarter. It seems like an impressive number given the comp. I think you guys had some pull forward recognized in the second quarter. So what is Ultimate Team up here to date? And can you comment on the expectations in Ultimate Team going forward? And then I have a follow-up.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't have the year-to-date number with me here. But it's fairly consistent with what it was in the quarter. Just off the top of my head, we're continuing to see that. Remember, we had a slowdown in FIFA Ultimate Team in the fourth quarter last yea
componenttext: Yes, I don't have the year-to-date number with me here. But it's fairly consistent with what it was in the quarter. Just off the top of my head, we're continuing to see that. Remember, we had a slowdown in FIFA Ultimate Team in the fourth quarter last year as we put the price branding into address the inflation in the marketplace issue that we saw. We are currently forecasting that we'll have a stronger fourth quarter than we did last year because obviously, we had corrected some of those pricing issues. So we should continue to see strong growth of Ultimate Team through the year and probably for the full year, clearly, exceed because of the lean last quarter last year. But, clearly, the business continues to grow and we've done a good job of bringing new users in. So we're not taxing the existing users, but it gets harder and harder to grow the business at the size that it's at. So we'll see what it looks like for next year. The other thing that really, remember, as you're looking at is realize that a huge portion of the Ultimate Team audience for FIFA is outside the U.S., large markets like France, Germany, U.K. And so all of those markets have a headwind from FX in that we're clearly seeing in the growth numbers. So as I mentioned today, 18% on a constant currency basis for Ultimate Team or for FIFA and that's a pretty impressive growth rate on the business of that size.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And aspirational number on R&D as a percent of revenue, how important is call in less profitable or non profitable titles in the portfolio? Do you have an opportunity to do that going forward? How do you think about limiting the number of SKUs goi
componenttext: Got it. And aspirational number on R&D as a percent of revenue, how important is call in less profitable or non profitable titles in the portfolio? Do you have an opportunity to do that going forward? How do you think about limiting the number of SKUs going forward?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Drew, we're down to less than 15 major SKUs and that deal is the good size of the business. So we're obviously, announcing that we're investing in some action-based SKUs by bringing people like Jade Raymond and Amy Heading into our organization to b
componenttext: Well, Drew, we're down to less than 15 major SKUs and that deal is the good size of the business. So we're obviously, announcing that we're investing in some action-based SKUs by bringing people like Jade Raymond and Amy Heading into our organization to build those and those are obviously a few years out in our SKU plan. But, clearly, we want to try to grow genres and grow our revenue base with more titles, both digital live services titles as well as traditional console titles. Part of -- to do that part of it is we have to be as ruthless that we don't spend a lot of money on smaller titles, we size them correctly. But we also wanted to continue to look for ways to bring new, interesting titles to the market. Look at Unravel, it's a perfect case of that. We're trying to address the marketplace for broader another titles that address the wider audience in terms of the types of games they are and the types of games people wanted to play. We're also trying to build enough products to be able to effectively run subscription-based businesses and that requires a great portfolio, which we have and we'll continue to add to. So we always call, but there's not a ton of things to cut back on today because we've brought the total number of titles down to a very perfect time to for us soon.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Ben Schachter.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Ben Schachter.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's been a lot of positive commentary including Star Wars and getting reorders in 4Q, but we don't see that really flow-through for the fiscal year guidance. So I'm wondering if you could talk more about why and is it all weakness in prior gen? Is it
componenttext: There's been a lot of positive commentary including Star Wars and getting reorders in 4Q, but we don't see that really flow-through for the fiscal year guidance. So I'm wondering if you could talk more about why and is it all weakness in prior gen? Is it at all FX? Is there anything else going on that we should know about? Secondly, FIFA in China, can you talk about how meaningfully we should be thinking about that business for FY '17? And then finally, of course, I have to ask another of your question and understanding it's not getting meaningful for a number of years, is it possible that we'll get any of those sort of the defined EA experiments or small experiences? Any chance we'll get those in calendar '16?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ben, I guess, I would remind people that we did raise full year guidance, that's the third time this year we've raised full year guidance. We've got a track record, I think, of 10 quarters in a row beating our guidance. I think we've exhibited some conser
componenttext: Ben, I guess, I would remind people that we did raise full year guidance, that's the third time this year we've raised full year guidance. We've got a track record, I think, of 10 quarters in a row beating our guidance. I think we've exhibited some conservatism on how we operate the business, which we think is a prudent thing to do. And we're sitting with an FX headwind and a lot of uncertainty in the economy. You put all that together, I don't think that signals anything negative about the fourth quarter, it signals the way we've been approaching the business and operating the business and that's what we're going to continue to do. In terms of FIFA Online 3 in China, the key there is we're continuing to see very positive reactions, but we also have very long-term view there. So a continued level that we've talked about 10 million to 15 million a quarter is still consistent with where we are. And when we give you guidance in the May time frame, we'll update that number if it looks like it should be updated. But it's all very positive in that and our partner, Tencent, continues to be extremely happy. With that maybe, I'll let Andrew hit the VR question if there's anything.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, not a lot more to say at this point. No announcement as to launch times or something we're experimenting at this stage. But as we go into calendar '16, as we start to come closer to our You EA Player events in L.A. and in London, we're talking more ab
componenttext: No, not a lot more to say at this point. No announcement as to launch times or something we're experimenting at this stage. But as we go into calendar '16, as we start to come closer to our You EA Player events in L.A. and in London, we're talking more about our fall titles slated and some other new in development products that we're running across our studios right now.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Neil Doshi.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Neil Doshi.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: 2 questions, Blake, can you talk a little bit about the macro environment and kind of what you guys are seeing as you move into calendar '16? And then secondly, we've noticed, I think, Amazon announced that they're putting out a promotion for prime member
componenttext: 2 questions, Blake, can you talk a little bit about the macro environment and kind of what you guys are seeing as you move into calendar '16? And then secondly, we've noticed, I think, Amazon announced that they're putting out a promotion for prime members every time a large shipper or a game goes up for sale and preorder a couple of weeks after, they're going to give a pretty hefty 20% discount. Can you talk about whether you guys are helping to fund that? Or if that's something Amazon is just kind of taking on their own? And how do you think that could potentially impact digital sales primary for physical discs?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the macro environment, we've mentioned a couple of times, our caution because of the macro environment, we have not seen anything in our business or heard anything from other players in the business that would imply any economic slow down in entertainm
componenttext: On the macro environment, we've mentioned a couple of times, our caution because of the macro environment, we have not seen anything in our business or heard anything from other players in the business that would imply any economic slow down in entertainment software. I said, we have a level of conservatism about just the global economy, which at some point in time, there's trouble in the global economy that would impact everybody probably. I think our business seems to be operating pretty consistent as it has been over the last couple of years. The console purchases up through the end of calendar year '15, our estimate is 55 million units out there, which has exceeded virtually everyone's forecast for the year and is now almost 50% higher than the previous console cycle. So all of that is very, very positive, all the gameplay we're seeing and the engagement and things like Ultimate teams are seeing as positive, we're just conscious of the fact that there's a lot of storm out there, we want to be careful that we don't get ahead of ourselves or the economy in our forecast for the business and that's what you're hearing. The second part of the question was the Amazon issue, we do not fund the Amazon discount that comes out of Amazon. I think that's fairly consistent with how Amazon operates. And we don't have much say or view on pricing of anyone in the marketplace. That's their job, not our job. For us, if it brings new gameplayers into the business, then we're excited. But we don't really have much more to say or control over their pricing strategy.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from the line of Doug Creutz.
componenttext: Our next question is from the line of Doug Creutz.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: You guys announced your EA Play a few days and obviously maybe an interesting decision to not have a boost in the floor of your 3 this year. Just curious as to your thinking about why do that if I recall one of the major competitors made similar decisions
componenttext: You guys announced your EA Play a few days and obviously maybe an interesting decision to not have a boost in the floor of your 3 this year. Just curious as to your thinking about why do that if I recall one of the major competitors made similar decisions several years ago ultimately, decided it was not the way to go. So is there anything that's changed that led you to that decision?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So what we have seen is more and more, we need to be close to our players and what you've seen from us the last couple of years in almost all of our actions, whether it relates to development or marketing or sales, is attempts by our endeavors, by us to g
componenttext: So what we have seen is more and more, we need to be close to our players and what you've seen from us the last couple of years in almost all of our actions, whether it relates to development or marketing or sales, is attempts by our endeavors, by us to get as close as possible to our players and get direct feedback from them, we believe that's the single best way to ensure that we're making games that they want to play. And we're making some of the best games in the industry. And we see this is an opportunity to do just that, just get close to our player, invite them in, in an environment where they feel comfortable to play games, give us feedback and interact socially as they do, whether it's through social network or with their friends or what have you. We continue to be members of the ESA and we will have meeting rooms at each [indiscernible]. So what we us we're doing is augmenting the overall experience, and we're excited by what we're going to be able to do as it relates to EA Play and we're excited from what the industry is able to do as it relates to each of the 3 more broadly.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And to add to that, we're also doing a simultaneous event in London. And so in some ways, we're trying to do a more geographically spread way to introduce people to our new product.
componenttext: And to add to that, we're also doing a simultaneous event in London. And so in some ways, we're trying to do a more geographically spread way to introduce people to our new product.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our last question is from the line of Eric Handler.
componenttext: Our last question is from the line of Eric Handler.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just under the wire there. Two things for you. First, with Start Wars, obviously, you're not making a Star Wars movie game, but you got nice leverage off of the Force Awakens this December. How are you thinking about what you can do with Star Wars Battlef
componenttext: Just under the wire there. Two things for you. First, with Start Wars, obviously, you're not making a Star Wars movie game, but you got nice leverage off of the Force Awakens this December. How are you thinking about what you can do with Star Wars Battlefront next December when the first spin-off movie comes out World 1? Is there much you can do around that to keep monetization levels high? And then secondly, looking at your mobile business, after the first 2 quarters of the year, mobile was really stagnant, you got strong growth in the third quarter with Madden and Star Wars. As we think about the mobile business going forward, does this sort of the inflection point where we start seeing some reacceleration of revenue or sustainable as the improvements there? Or maybe talk about some of your plans at mobile?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll start with Star Wars, I don't know, Andrew, might want to chime in on the mobile piece. On Star Wars, the one thing that we are hearing to and, I think, this is part of our arrangement with Lucas and Disney is you can't make a game in Star Wars that
componenttext: I'll start with Star Wars, I don't know, Andrew, might want to chime in on the mobile piece. On Star Wars, the one thing that we are hearing to and, I think, this is part of our arrangement with Lucas and Disney is you can't make a game in Star Wars that violates that canon of Star Wars. Meaning, you can't take something from the future and bring it back into the past unless it's a reference. Not knowing yet exactly what the storyline what was going to be, I can't comment on how that could come in because the extent is in the future around our current game is also based on the historical Star Wars canon, which is 30 years before the most recent movie, that will limit our ability to bring some new content into that. But more to come there, obviously, we're trying to stay tightly connected to the Star Wars beat for future movies. And we'll obviously, in future Star Wars games be able to tap the new characters and vehicles and so forth. But in our current game and for that matter, the DLC associated with that current game, obviously, we'll have to be careful that we don't violate the canon. On mobile, obviously, mobile, one thing to remember is like our console business, mobile will always be a little choppy based on when new titles come out. But like most live services, they should be smoother than the historical beats around the console business. So over time, we hope to smooth that out. But there's still maybe some jumps up and down at the 2 quarters.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, on the Star Wars play, just to add a little, I mean, what we have seen is that the movie or the content of the movie itself hasn't impeded the engagement in various Star Wars games, you've seen that across console, PC and mobile. And we would expect
componenttext: Yes, on the Star Wars play, just to add a little, I mean, what we have seen is that the movie or the content of the movie itself hasn't impeded the engagement in various Star Wars games, you've seen that across console, PC and mobile. And we would expect that more great Star Wars films come out, we would see more great engagement in Star Wars content more broadly, again not just in Battlefront, but in Star Wars : The Old Republic and mobile game, Galaxy of Heroes. As we think about mobile, just to add to Blake's point, he's absolutely right, the 1 other thing that we would point to is as we look at our mobile portfolio, our titles typically have very long life spans. Sims FreePlay, the Simpsons Tapped Out, Real Racing 3 have continued to grow over a number of years. And as we think about launching new titles, we're taking a little more targeted, being a little bit more calculated about how we launch, but we're doing so with a view that we are putting experience in the marketplace that will live for many years and drive engagement and profitability for a number of years to come. And so as we look at the year to come as we look at what we've done with Star Wars and Madden and some other titles that are coming down the chute, our expectation is that we're able to grow the overall business with them.
