headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, my name is Jennifer and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Electronic Arts Fourth Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] I'll now turn the conference over to Chris E
componenttext: Good afternoon, my name is Jennifer and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Electronic Arts Fourth Quarter 2016 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] I'll now turn the conference over to Chris Evenden, Vice President of Investor Relations. Sir, you may begin.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jennifer. Welcome to EA's fiscal 2016 fourth quarter earnings call. With me on the call today are Andrew Wilson, our CEO; and Blake Jorgensen, our CFO. Please note that our SEC filings and our earnings release are available at ir.ea.com. In add
componenttext:
Thank you, Jennifer. Welcome to EA's fiscal 2016 fourth quarter earnings call. With me on the call today are Andrew Wilson, our CEO; and Blake Jorgensen, our CFO. Please note that our SEC filings and our earnings release are available at ir.ea.com. In addition, we have posted earnings slides to accompany our prepared remarks. After the call, we will post our prepared remarks, an audio replay of this call and a transcript.
A couple of quick notes on our calendar. We plan to deliver our next earnings report on Tuesday, August 2. And our press conference at EA Play will take place at 1:00 p.m. Pacific Time on Sunday June 12. Coming up next week on Tuesday, May 17, is our Investor Day. If you haven't registered already, please contact me so that we can send you an invitation.
This presentation and our comments include forward-looking statements regarding future events and the future financial performance of the company. Actual events and results may differ materially from our expectations. We refer you to our most recent Form 10-Q for a discussion of risks that could cause actual results to differ materially from those discussed today. Electronic Arts makes these statements as of today, May 10, 2016, and disclaims any duty to update them.
During this call, unless otherwise stated, the financial metrics will be presented on a non-GAAP basis. Our earnings release and the earnings slides provide a reconciliation of our GAAP to non-GAAP measures. These non-GAAP measures are not intended to be considered in isolation from, as a substitute for, or superior to, our GAAP results. We encourage investors to consider all measures before making an investment decision. All comparisons made in the course of this call are against the same period in the prior year unless otherwise stated.
Now I'll turn the call over to Andrew.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Chris.FY '16 was a phenomenal year for Electronic Arts. Our non-GAAP revenue, earnings and cash flow for the year were all at record level and exceeded our guidance. It was a year of growth and milestones demonstrating our unique ability to conn
componenttext:
Thanks, Chris.
FY '16 was a phenomenal year for Electronic Arts. Our non-GAAP revenue, earnings and cash flow for the year were all at record level and exceeded our guidance. It was a year of growth and milestones demonstrating our unique ability to connect hundreds of millions of players across genres, geographies and platforms to the games they love and to each other.
To highlight a few examples, we keep up a new generation of Star Wars games from Electronic Arts for the extraordinary successful games on console, PC and mobile. Nearly 54 million unique players engaged in our EA SPORTS console titles during the year, up 65% from last year. Across our portfolio of live services, we launched hundreds of content updates throughout the year, bringing players deeper into their favorite games. Our SIMS 4 player base grew by almost 2/3 throughout the year and our Battlefield franchise saw 9.4 million unique players in Q4 alone. In addition, players are spending more time with our new games and ongoing franchises on mobile.
Engagement is Star Wars Galaxy of Heroes is exceptional with players spending nearly 2 hours per day on average in the game during Q4. Madden NFL Mobile continues its strong performance with engagement up more than 30% in Q4 over last year. And the SIMS FreePlay has now reached 200 million installs left today.
With all of our games and live services, our focus continues to be on putting players first and delivering unmatched creativity, depth and value. Engagement is critical in today's world where everyone faces such intense competition for time. Combining great franchises, innovative IP and sophisticated services, we continue to build network, global communities for our games where players can connect to more great content and to their friends maximizing the fun every time they play.
As we move into FY '17, we're incredibly excited to launch a slate of groundbreaking new games and add to the breadth of live services available to our players. Our first new game this fiscal year will be Mirrors Age Catalyst, launching on June 7, with fluid movement and combat stunning beauty by our frostbite engine. The first of our EA SPORTS title for this year, Madden NFL 17, NHL 17, and FIFA 17, arriving Q2, each taking a major leap forward in personalization, immersion and competition. We're also working on a new and engaging way to place into our NBA Live franchise on consoles, and we'll share more on that in the quarters ahead.
In the global livestream last Friday that was watched by more than 2 million people, Battlefield 1 made its debut. Fans got their first look into the intense visual combat and epic scale of this groundbreaking new game from Dice and the response was immediate and extraordinary. That trailer was viewed more than 21 million times in the first 4 days, a new record for EA and it's now our most like trailer in history. With Battlefield 1, we've set out to deliver the biggest and most innovative Battlefield game ever, with a deep story and unprecedented variety and a gameplay powered by our frostbite engine. Battlefield 1 is set to launch worldwide on October 21.
In partnership with the talent team of Respawn Entertainment, Titanfall 2 will launch in Q3. The first Titanfall delivered a fast, fluid experience that invigorated players and ignited the genre. Titanfall 2 will come to play on PlayStation 4 and Xbox One and PC. The excitement from friends -- the excitement from fans since our official announcement over the game has been outstanding and we can't wait to debut the first gameplay from Titanfall 2 at EA play on June 12.
Late in the fourth quarter, Mass Effect: Andromeda will bring an all-new story to the critically acclaimed RPG series from BioWare. And throughout the year, mobile players will see launches from some of our biggest brands, building on the continued success of Madden NFL Mobile, we're excited to bring you EA SPORTS experiences from our NBA Live and FIFA franchises to place in FY '17. Friends of our pocket franchise will have new experiences as well with Bejeweled Stars launching today and Plants vs. Zombies Heroes set to arrive later this year. 
Our excitement for the year extends well beyond our title slate. The gaming industry continues to rapidly evolve and grow and in each dimension, EA is at the leading-edge. In addition to being the #1 publisher in the Western World on Xbox One and PlayStation 4 in FY '16 and the most downloaded mobile game publisher in calendar year 2015, we are investing deeply to finding new growth opportunities.
Our competitive gaming programs will seek to engage players at all skill levels with competitions like Madden NFL 16 Championship being just the tip of the iceberg. Our unparalleled Frostbite Engine will power more of our games this year, including an all-new Star Wars Battlefront experience for PlayStation VR. In addition to delivering strong and stable service architectures, our technology platform teams continue to implement a cross-platform, cross-title identity system to help our players stay connected to their games and their friends.
Across our studio teams, partnered by [indiscernible] Sport Entertainment and the [indiscernible] Groups, we are working on more new ideas, technologies and IP. And this June in Los Angeles and London, EA Play will bring players closer to our games and help them share those expenses with the world.
FY '16 was the strongest year in the history of Electronic Arts and we are just getting started. Looking to FY '17 and beyond, we are confident that our trajectory is even stronger.
Now I'll turn the call over to Blake for a deeper look at our financials.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Andrew.The end of the year is a good point in which to reflect on the progress we've made and it has been a great year. Using non-GAAP metrics, fiscal 2016 revenue at $4.57 billion was an all-time record. Our operating margin at just 9.5% 4 year
componenttext:
Thanks, Andrew.
The end of the year is a good point in which to reflect on the progress we've made and it has been a great year. Using non-GAAP metrics, fiscal 2016 revenue at $4.57 billion was an all-time record. Our operating margin at just 9.5% 4 years ago was 28.5% this year, its highest ever. Gross margin at 71.4% and earnings at over $1 billion were also all-time records, as was operating cash flow at $1.2 billion. We were able to deliver those results despite significant FX headwinds, which impacted our top line by over $300 million.
Digital revenue was now 55% of our business, up from 52% last year. Extra content was a record $1.1 billion. Within that, our Ultimate Team business reached $692 million, up 18% at actual FX and up 26% at constant currency.
Our mobile business delivered another record year at $570 million in revenue. During the year, we returned over $1 billion to shareholders through repurchasing stock, again a record.
Moving to the specifics of the fourth quarter results. EA's non-GAAP net revenue was $924 million, which was $49 million above our guidance and $28 million above last year. The quarter's outperformance was driven by digital, particularly Ultimate Team and our mobile live services. Ultimate Team continues to thrive as do our mobile titles  led by Star Wars Galaxy of Heroes and Madden NFL Mobile. EA's Q4 non-GAAP digital net revenue was $720 million. This resulted in a full year digital revenue of more than $2.5 billion.
Breaking down Q4's digital revenue into its key components highlights the performance of each of these businesses. First, extra content and PC free-to-play contributed $310 million, up 26% over the prior year. The key driver was FIFA Ultimate Team, which grew 38% in the face of significant FX headwinds. At constant currency, our FIFA Ultimate Team business would have been up 48% year-on-year.
Second, our mobile business generated $173 million for the quarter, up 15% over prior year. Growth was led by Star Wars Galaxy of Heroes and Madden NFL Mobile. The strength of these mobile live services add to the broad portfolio of EA mobile games, which delivered a consistent and profitable revenue streams.
Third, full game downloads added $134 million to the quarter, up 18% year-on-year.
And finally, subscriptions, advertising and other digital revenue totaled $95 million, up $4 million over the same period last year.
Moving on to gross margin. Our non-GAAP gross margin for the quarter was 76.9%, 90 basis points above our guidance due to the strength of digital, particularly Ultimate Team and our mobile business. It was up from 75.4% in Q4 fiscal '15.
Non-GAAP operating expenses for the quarter were $499 million, down $14 million from last year and $1 million lower than our guidance. The resulting non-GAAP diluted EPS for the quarter was $0.50 per share, $0.10 above our guidance and $0.11 above prior year.
One note as you review our GAAP operating expenses related to our guidance. GAAP earnings for fiscal 2016 includes a material income tax credit due to the reversal of the valuation allowance we had against our U.S. deferred tax assets. This credit was $453 million increased our diluted GAAP EPS for fiscal '16 by $1.37 per share to a total of $3.50. But it had no effect on non-GAAP earnings or on cash flow.
Net cash provided by operating activities for the quarter was $396 million compared to $198 million in prior year, primarily due to Star Wars Battlefront. Operating cash flow for the full fiscal year hit its highest level in company history at $1.22 billion, a 15% increase over last year's cash flow of $1.07 billion and above our raise guidance. We continue to grow cash flow due to the underlying strength of the business and the greater profitability unlocked by our digital transformation.
Fiscal '16 capital expenditures were $93 million resulting in free cash flow of $1.13 billion.
During the quarter, we raised $1 billion in the form of 5- and 10-year investment grade senior notes. In connection with this, we also announced the $500 million stock repurchase program over and above the 2-year $1 billion program we already have in place. We completed this new program in the quarter and continued our steady progress on the ongoing program, resulting in a total repurchases quarter of 9.9 million shares of common stock at an average price of $63.70 per share. This leaves $539 million from the 2-year program available for repurchases.
For the fiscal year, we returned over $1 billion to shareholders through the repurchase of 15.7 million shares, approximately 5% of shares outstanding. As a result, we estimated our fiscal non-GAAP diluted share count will be 319 million shares.
During Q4, we settled $177 million in early conversions of our convertible notes. Through March 31, we redeemed $470 million of the $633 million total and as of yesterday, we received notices for an additional $27 million to settle in Q1. Dilutions from these redemptions, the warrants and future redemptions are already accounted for in our non-GAAP diluted share count.
Our cash and short-term investments at the end of the quarter were $3.83 billion, or $12.74 per share. Approximately 47% of this was held in the U.S.
Now on to fiscal 2017 guidance. With regards to the market, we expect sales of current generation consoles to continue at a rapid pace, with another 25 million units to be sold this calendar year, adding to the 55 million units in place at the end of calendar 2015. In addition to the console, we expect our mobile franchises to benefit from the continued expansion of iOS and Android and we're continuing to see strength in PC gaming.
We expect non-GAAP revenue to increase approximately 7% to $4.9 billion. The anticipated strength is broad-based, primarily driven by the launches of Battlefield 1, Titanfall 2 and Mass Effect: Andromeda. Other important drivers include the continued growth of our core sport titles of associated live services and the expansion of our mobile business.
The expected phasing of our revenue is disclosed in the earnings presentation posted to our website. The non-GAAP gross margin is expected to arrive 110 basis points to 72.5%, driven by the increase in digital revenue and improved product mix. The margin benefits from the wholly-owned IP of Battlefield 1 and Mass Effect Andromeda are partially offset by the royalty fee associated with Titanfall 2. We expect non-GAAP operating expenses of $2.1 billion, up almost $140 million from fiscal '16. The increase is driven by our new investments in new franchises, particularly in the action genre, an extension of our partnership with Respawn, our digital player platform, competitive gaming and new mobile games. These are offset somewhat by FX. This would deliver an operating margin of 29.7% and non-GAAP EPS of $3.50, up 11% year-on-year. This includes the addition of $41 million in new interest expense on our recent debt offering, but is partially offset by a reduction in our non-GAAP tax rate from 22% to 21% and the reduction in our share count to 319 million.
The change in tax rate is due to the continued growth of our business outside of the United States and the interest on our debt. The change in share count was driven by the additional $500 million repurchased in the quarter. And with regards to forecasted share count, note that our standard practice is to include an estimate of dilution for our employee equity programs but not to factor in any potential reduction from our ongoing buyback program.
The earnings presentation in our investor website contains more information about our exchange rate assumptions for the year.
Segmenting the sales provides further insights to the key drivers of our full year non-GAAP revenue guidance. Package growth and other revenue was forecasted to be approximately $2 billion, down slightly, driven by the continued shift to digital delivery and offset by growth in sales. Digital revenue is forecasted to be $2.9 billion, up 15%. 
Breaking down our digital revenue into its 4 primary categories, we see the contributions from each group: Our mobile business is expected to grow approximately 15% as we add new titles to our diverse and successful bases of live services. As part of this, we'll leverage the learnings from the success of Madden NFL Mobile to our other sports titles.
Revenue from full game downloads is anticipated to grow 25%. We saw a strong growth in digital download in fiscal '16. For example, downloads of the Madden for all consoles are up 15% year-on-year and we expect this trend to continue.
Extra content and free-to-download is expected to grow approximately 10% this year, driven by premium offerings for Star Wars Battlefront and by the Ultimate Team. Battlefront extra content started to contribute in Q4 and we're expecting an attach rate for Season Pass of around 10%. 
Lastly, subscription revenue is expected to grow approximately 10% this year, driven by growth in Origin Access and EA Access and partially offset by the fall off of Battlefield 4 Premium revenue. On a GAAP basis, guidance is for net revenue of $4.75 billion, gross margin of 71% and operating expenses around $2.31 billion and EPS of $2.53.
Finally, cash flow will continue to be a key metric for us going forward. In fiscal 2017, we're forecasting operating cash flow of approximately $1.3 billion and capital expenses of approximately $110 million, resulting in free cash flow of approximately $1.2 billion, up from $1.1 billion in fiscal 2016. The anticipated increase in CapEx is primarily due to upgrades to our platform infrastructure and facilities.
Focusing now on Q1. Non-GAAP revenue for the quarter is expected to be $640 million, an 8% decrease compared to last year's $693 million. The year-ago quarter benefited from more favorable exchange rates, Battlefield Hardline catalog, a one-off recognition of revenue from FIFA Online 3 in China and the fact that it was a 14-week quarter versus 13-week this year.
Non-GAAP gross margins is forecasted to be approximately 74.5%. Non-GAAP operating expenses are expected to be $485 million, $13 million higher than last year, driven by investments in future products offset by the fact that it's a shorter quarter and by a stronger dollar.
For the quarter, we expect a non-GAAP loss of $0.05 per share as compared to earnings of $0.15 per diluted share last year. GAAP revenue is expected to be $1.25 billion as compared to $1.2 billion in the prior year and GAAP diluted EPS is expected to be $1.30 as compared to $1.32 per share in the prior year.
As we look forward towards Q2, please note that FIFA 16 launched 2 weeks ahead of the end of Q2 fiscal '16 rather than the usual 1 week. The extra week enabled us to capture an extra week of FIFA sales. This was primarily high-margin Ultimate Team and digital revenue and boosted the quarter by approximately $75 million. This year, we'll see a return to a more typical pattern with a much greater concentration of operating income in Q3 and Q4.
In conclusion, it was a great year for EA with financial and engagement record set across-the-board. Looking forward, we're embracing digital to continue to drive the business. We expect these trends, along with growing sales of our existing titles and new franchises underdevelopment, to continue to drive strong revenue, EPS and cash flow growth into the future.
Now I'll turn the call back to Andrew.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Blake.Our industry continues to grow. Across the world, more players are engaging in more games on more platforms across more geographies and business models. Yet as our [indiscernible] expands, it is evolving as well. The competition for timing
componenttext:
Thanks, Blake.
Our industry continues to grow. Across the world, more players are engaging in more games on more platforms across more geographies and business models. Yet as our [indiscernible] expands, it is evolving as well. The competition for timing there is no room for transit experiences. Players expect more from the games they play and in return, they will spend more time in the games they love.
In the world where discoveries are increasingly difficult and engagement decision are made every second, connecting players with the right experience when and where they want to play is critical.
In this transforming world, our focus continues to be on meeting and exceeding our players needs through direct relationships at the value at every return. Today, Electronic Arts engages hundreds of millions of players and in the future, potentially billions. Through great games and live services in our powerful brands, alike Battlefield, FIFA, Star Wars, the Sims, Plants vs. Zombies, Mass Effect and more. This portfolio of IP, combined with great talent and robust technology in our underlying platform differentiates EA in our ability to connect players to more games, to more friends and more ways to engage in a global network of play.
It always begins with great games. And in FY '17, we'll deliver some of the creative, engaging and biggest experiences today from Electronic Arts. We also continue to foster and grow thriving communities across our portfolio of live services. Our teams are leveraging technologies, like Frostbite, to deliver new experiences across more devices. As we evolve our core platform, we are learning more about our players and adding capabilities to unlock greater value for them.
New programs, including competitive gaming, will help us reach and connect more players around the world. These are the dimensions of connected players that to date, players seek and Electronic Arts is positioned to lead. These are foundational times for the future of games and how we play them. We're excited that FY '17 and beyond and look forward to sharing more with you in the quarters ahead.
With that, Blake and I will take your questions.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Justin Post with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And our first question comes from the line of Justin Post with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016

componenttext: Two questions. Can you talk about your investment this year and your guidance for the action-adventure titles? And could we see something as soon as fiscal '18 on that front? And then a large competitor, maybe this is for Andrew, talked a lot about EA SPORTS and how do you see that opportunity for your first-person shooters and also your big sports titles?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Justin, good question and I'll start with the investment piece. We're making broad investments that fuel the growth of the company well beyond fiscal '18 and '19. Really today, we're building an action genre product that's probably in our fiscal '20 or
componenttext: So Justin, good question and I'll start with the investment piece. We're making broad investments that fuel the growth of the company well beyond fiscal '18 and '19. Really today, we're building an action genre product that's probably in our fiscal '20 or '21, as well as action-oriented games around the Star Wars genre. Most of what we're investing in this incremental now probably comes in fiscal '19 and '20. But, clearly, some of our investment is to grow out the product base for what we're going on as well. We do have a new IP coming next year, we haven't yet announced it, but it's something that you'll see from probably coming up soon and clearly, that's one of our investment franchise as well as continuing out, building out the Battlefront franchise with Star Wars for fiscal '18 as well.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As it relates to competitive gaming, Peter Moore, our head of Competitive Gaming group, is going to deliver a lot more in terms of understanding at our upcoming Investor Day. The group overwrote is focused on enabling global communities through great
componenttext: Yes. As it relates to competitive gaming, Peter Moore, our head of Competitive Gaming group, is going to deliver a lot more in terms of understanding at our upcoming Investor Day. The group overwrote is focused on enabling global communities through great games. So this absolutely includes the elite division, but we also believe there's an opportunity to celebrate the talent and skill at every level of gameplay. So for some, that will mean a leap play, for others that will just mean the joy of competition with friends. And we believe there's going to be a robust community and result engagement and we can build as a result of that.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question is from Chris Merwin of Barclays.
componenttext: And your next question is from Chris Merwin of Barclays.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. First of all, on extra content that reaccelerated nicely in the fiscal fourth quarter. So wondering if you could provide a bit more color on what drove the improvement there? I think you called out mid-20% constant currency growth,
componenttext: A couple of questions. First of all, on extra content that reaccelerated nicely in the fiscal fourth quarter. So wondering if you could provide a bit more color on what drove the improvement there? I think you called out mid-20% constant currency growth, but it was also sort of curious what lift you got from the Star Wars DOC as well? And then just a second question on non-GAAP gross margins, I think you've got at about 100 basis points of margin expansion year-on-year, which is consistent with the long-term guidance. But just curious what that assume for digital downloads as a percentage of total for the year? And how the download patterns for Battlefield 1 might differ from Star Wars Battlefront?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So extra content, obviously, was dominated by Ultimate Team, but also FIFA Online 3 in Asia continues to grow, [indiscernible] falls in that. We saw continued growth of our original Star Wars products, Star Wars : The Old Republic, as well as extra c
componenttext: Yes. So extra content, obviously, was dominated by Ultimate Team, but also FIFA Online 3 in Asia continues to grow, [indiscernible] falls in that. We saw continued growth of our original Star Wars products, Star Wars : The Old Republic, as well as extra content associated with the SIMS, with Battlefield -- or Battlefield 4 and, obviously, the start of the Battlefront extra content. The bulk of that though is on components I just mentioned. It really drove outsized performance in the quarter for extra content. In terms of guidance going forward, assumptions around full game downloads, we assume that we're continuing to see growth that we saw in the past year. Industry now is above[ph] 30%, I think it's reaching 32% and we're fairly consistent with that, with some titles as we mentioned in the script, they're well north of that. Jim 4, Madden, for example, was well north of 50% when you look at the full year number. So you're starting to see dramatic movements there. We should see greater improvement next year because we won't have the skewing towards physical that we saw in the Battlefront giftgiving at we saw around the holiday, we mentioned it in our last quarter. And that forecast is driven what we're seeing at our uptick, about 110% in gross margin growth year-over-year.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question is from Steven Ju of Credit Suisse.
componenttext: And your next question is from Steven Ju of Credit Suisse.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Andrew, I'm looking at the proposed release slate for '17, I think you have Titanfall launching alongside Battlefield and NBA launch during the basketball season. So obviously, you got the spring's up concerns around cannibalization and missed timing. So
componenttext: Andrew, I'm looking at the proposed release slate for '17, I think you have Titanfall launching alongside Battlefield and NBA launch during the basketball season. So obviously, you got the spring's up concerns around cannibalization and missed timing. So I'm wondering if you could offer some additional perspective there. And also what do you think the underlying factors were that drove success for Madden mobile and Galaxy of Heroes? And how much this could be replicated in your other mobile sports or action movies releases?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So in terms of the Titanfall Battlefield one question, this is a giant category in our industry, $4.5 billion category. There's a very broader diverse players who played games in that category who are looking for a little different gameplay motivatio
componenttext: Yes. So in terms of the Titanfall Battlefield one question, this is a giant category in our industry, $4.5 billion category. There's a very broader diverse players who played games in that category who are looking for a little different gameplay motivations. Some people play very quick play, some a little more strategic play, some people want both in different context. The result of that, we still like we're acting a really strong position to deliver the broadest set of gameplay mechanics as it relates to first-person shooter genre across the 2 titles. I feel very confident that we are well-positioned to do very well in that category in the year. Certainly, as you see the reception around Battlefield 1, we feel very good about that. The energy around Titanfall 2 is also building very nice, we look forward to showing more with what of those, both of those titles at EA Play in June. As it relates to Madden mobile and Galaxy of Heroes, there's really a couple of things that we believe we are in a place to better understand now. One is how to best manifest sports IP or in fact large-scale IP, like Star Wars, in the mobile space and what that means in terms of screen size, session time, UI and just general gameplay mechanics. But perhaps the bigger opportunity that we feel like we capturing now is the opportunity for live service. These are not get games, the teams launch what is a spectacular game and then work diligently with the community to make that game bigger, better, more dynamic and more diverse on every given day. And we believe we have an opportunity across our sports games, certainly, but also across some of our other very well-known and well-recognized IP in the industry.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Steven, I think the good analogy is, the successful formula that drives Ultimate Team is continual event and activities, Team of the Week example -- would be a great example. We're using that same approach in many of our mobile games to drive that sa
componenttext: Yes. Steven, I think the good analogy is, the successful formula that drives Ultimate Team is continual event and activities, Team of the Week example -- would be a great example. We're using that same approach in many of our mobile games to drive that same type of engagement where people are continually coming back because we're making the game exciting, fresh, new and competitive. And that's exactly what people want to get out the experience that they've invested time in it. It's a great formula and we certainly, as we mentioned on the call, hope to be able to leverage that in our other sports games as well as nonsports games.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Colin Sebastian with Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Colin Sebastian with Robert W. Baird.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have a couple of questions. First one to ask, a follow-up on Battlefield 1 and the selection of World War I as the background setting, on one hand sounds quite intriguing. And we know that the World War II genre in the past did quite well. So notwithsta
componenttext: I have a couple of questions. First one to ask, a follow-up on Battlefield 1 and the selection of World War I as the background setting, on one hand sounds quite intriguing. And we know that the World War II genre in the past did quite well. So notwithstanding that initial reception sounds very positive here. I wonder what customer testing says about the appeal of the historical events since the genre has been donated by futuristic backdrops and then I have one follow-up.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think it's a great question and certainly, one that we've been asked a number of times. When the team set out to deliver the next version of Battlefield, they wanted to do a lot of things with the game. They wanted to be biggest Battlefield game, t
componenttext: Yes. I think it's a great question and certainly, one that we've been asked a number of times. When the team set out to deliver the next version of Battlefield, they wanted to do a lot of things with the game. They wanted to be biggest Battlefield game, they wanted to be the most diverse Battlefield game. They wanted fundamentally new gameplay mechanics with evolution of story into war and in character storyline, evolution of machinery, evolution of weaponry, a real opportunity to build and grow inside of a battlefield universe. When I took a step back and asked themselves, what was the best place to set a game that had that kind of ambition, World War I was really the only place to do it. And what very few people remember from their History classes, I guess, is people road in to World War I on horses and came out on planes and tanks and submarines. And we think that level of innovation and evolution of battle in a short period of time gives us a tremendous opportunity to deliver a very epic and full-scale experience. I think what we've shown so far is a small taste of that, and we look forward to spending time and giving people even more information in a deeper look at that as we come into EA play in June.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Andrew, looking ahead in terms of Star Wars franchise, I wonder if you could update on the progress and the potential timing of the titles from Respawn and how they fit into the release cadence for that license over the next few years?
componenttext: Andrew, looking ahead in terms of Star Wars franchise, I wonder if you could update on the progress and the potential timing of the titles from Respawn and how they fit into the release cadence for that license over the next few years?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll most likely have at least 1 Star Wars title a year over the next 3 to 4 years. Next year, we will see Star Wars Battlefront back with bigger and better worlds because we now have the new movies to work off of not just the historical movies that we u
componenttext: We'll most likely have at least 1 Star Wars title a year over the next 3 to 4 years. Next year, we will see Star Wars Battlefront back with bigger and better worlds because we now have the new movies to work off of not just the historical movies that we used before. We also are working on Star Wars action game, that part of the [indiscernible] team is working as well as the visceral team. And that's most likely the following year. And as we've announced we're working with our partners, Respawn, to work on another Star Wars game. They're very excited about that, they were asking us to include them in the franchise and we felt that they could add a huge amount to a new title there. So the cadence should be at least every year along with the cadence of large and small movies that Disney is doing relative to their movie -- that Disney is doing relative to Star Wars. And then, obviously, we'll continue to layer in mobile dials where possible as well, that try to have a diverse Star Wars activity from shooters all the way through action and strategy. But at the same time, taking advantage of all of the new great IP that's being developed by our partners at Disney.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question is from Brian Pitz from Jefferies.
componenttext: And our next question is from Brian Pitz from Jefferies.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: One more on Battlefield. It's getting very positive reception on YouTube and other online forums so far to date. We don't actually recall such strong early interest in the franchise. Are there other internal metrics that you would provide to give us confi
componenttext: One more on Battlefield. It's getting very positive reception on YouTube and other online forums so far to date. We don't actually recall such strong early interest in the franchise. Are there other internal metrics that you would provide to give us confidence that this game is attracting ahead of the previous versions?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And again we have been delighted with the reception. It's our most liked trailer to date and depending on what metrics you look at from YouTube, it maybe the most liked trailer ever on YouTube. And we see that as a real positive sign for the franchis
componenttext: Yes. And again we have been delighted with the reception. It's our most liked trailer to date and depending on what metrics you look at from YouTube, it maybe the most liked trailer ever on YouTube. And we see that as a real positive sign for the franchise, the communities has been asking for innovation the community's been asking for something different. And our Dice team step out and build something truly epic and responded to the communities amount. And the feedback has been resoundingly positive. As it relates to how the game is tracking, the game is doing really, really well. We recently had equipment franchise reviews where more of the games are playable at this stage and that has never been the case in Battlefield before. The Frostbite Engine is robust in its foundation, and this is a very tried-and-true team who will build unbelievable experiences. And so we have deep confidence in them to execute against their ambition, and we look forward to demonstrating more of that at the EA Play in June.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: And like most of our large titles, you tend to see more and more during the summer games come late in the summertime, most likely some further gameplay in the form of a beta or something to that extent. So you'll have plenty of ways to better understand t
componenttext: And like most of our large titles, you tend to see more and more during the summer games come late in the summertime, most likely some further gameplay in the form of a beta or something to that extent. So you'll have plenty of ways to better understand the depth of the product and the excitement around the product as the next few months come by. And we'll try to keep you informed in our next earnings call and how we see the demand developing for the product.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Arvind Bhatia with Sterne Agee.
componenttext: Your next question is from Arvind Bhatia with Sterne Agee.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you could talk about Titanfall 2 a little bit and how we should think about the title relative to its predecessor in terms of units perhaps. Obviously, the previous one was very successful, but it has some unique circumstances, it wasn'
componenttext: I was wondering if you could talk about Titanfall 2 a little bit and how we should think about the title relative to its predecessor in terms of units perhaps. Obviously, the previous one was very successful, but it has some unique circumstances, it wasn't on all platforms. But I know it had a high attach rate as one of the early key titles. So if you could just put that in perspective.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Clearly, we're very excited about it. We've seen it a couple of times over the last few months and it's well along the way and it's evolved substantially from the first Titanfall. First Titanfall was fantastic, this has added a whole new level to the
componenttext: Yes. Clearly, we're very excited about it. We've seen it a couple of times over the last few months and it's well along the way and it's evolved substantially from the first Titanfall. First Titanfall was fantastic, this has added a whole new level to the game and the experience. It will be on both platforms, which, obviously, means a bigger audience for Titanfall, particularly with the Sony platform is the one that has the experience. So they will have a chance to experience the game. But at the same time, obviously, that attach won't be anywhere near as high as it was because it's one of the first AAA titles for the new Xbox One. And so, obviously, a lower attach. We think you're going to see numbers clearly larger than our Titanfall 1 franchise. And we've got good expectations for it, but we'll try to be prudent on how we forecast that in our guidance.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Michael Olson with Piper Jaffray.
componenttext: Your next question is from Michael Olson with Piper Jaffray.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a couple of questions, if I could. First, you might diver into this at Analyst Day, but in addition to continued mix shift towards full game downloads and digital add-on content, how do you think about the evolution of revenue mix over the next few
componenttext: I had a couple of questions, if I could. First, you might diver into this at Analyst Day, but in addition to continued mix shift towards full game downloads and digital add-on content, how do you think about the evolution of revenue mix over the next few years related to subscription, free-to-play, et cetera? I guess, should we anticipate much of a change or will it be kind of primarily a continuation of growth and full game downloads and add-on content that we're seeing today? And then second, regarding past comments that you made on revenue growth consistency, how disciplined do you plan to be on keeping revenue growth in the single digits? In other words, if it appears that it could be tracking towards double-digits through the year, would you push titles in the fiscal '18 in order to manage the growth rate?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So on the first piece, I think we will continue to see subscriptions grow, particularly with EA Access and the strength of that product. And, obviously, based on the strength of that, we rolled out Origin Access, which is our Origin-based PC-based ga
componenttext: Yes. So on the first piece, I think we will continue to see subscriptions grow, particularly with EA Access and the strength of that product. And, obviously, based on the strength of that, we rolled out Origin Access, which is our Origin-based PC-based gaming with a similar structure as EA Access. We'll continue to push of that. We think subscriptions are an important part of the future of this business and you'll see that continuing to grow. In the past, remember, we've had some accounting differences between products, where something that looks like DLC might have been booked as a subscription because it was the theory of DLCs over time. And that's what made the subscription number go up and down over time. You'll continue to probably see some of that as we have different accounting methods, but I think the combination of extra content, subscription should continue to be a larger and larger portion of our business over time. I think that's an important piece of the mix. I think also as you look at the business, you'll see greater mobile concentration of our growth and the combination of mobile, plus extra content subscriptions, is now starting to create a very nice foundation for the business. With that plus full-game downloads, we mentioned we're $2.5 billion, that's a wonderful foundation to make the revenue much smoother over time. On the revenue growth, let me be clear, it's not our aspiration to have single-digit revenue growth. It's our focus to try to maintain discipline on the operating model in the company. We don't want to over invest and not deliver the revenue. That's the problem we had historically. So we talk about single-digit revenue growth because that's how we think about our investment, but we're trying to drive higher revenue growth possible. And we'll do that on a case-by-case basis on the side of the revenue, if we can push the revenue harder or not, and sometimes products get moved based on when those product are ready or timing in the marketplace. But our goal is to try to drive both revenue, top line growth and drive earnings growth. And if we can get both of those in double-digit, that would be fantastic. We've been lucky enough to drive double-digit bottom line growth and we'll continue to see that over the next few years, we believe.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Andrew Crum from Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Andrew Crum from Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the guidance for OpEx this year is $2.1 billion, you kind of run through the details behind that. Is that a new normal or the run rate we should expect beyond fiscal '17?
componenttext: So the guidance for OpEx this year is $2.1 billion, you kind of run through the details behind that. Is that a new normal or the run rate we should expect beyond fiscal '17?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Probably in that zone, could be plus or minus $25 million or $30 million. I'll remind people a couple components of that, one is our marketing and sales, we try to target that number between 12% and 13% of revenue. So obviously, in a bigger revenue year l
componenttext: Probably in that zone, could be plus or minus $25 million or $30 million. I'll remind people a couple components of that, one is our marketing and sales, we try to target that number between 12% and 13% of revenue. So obviously, in a bigger revenue year like this year, we're going to spend more on in marketing and sales to support things like Battlefield and Titanfall. So that's going to see a flux up and down based on the revenue component. Our R&D expenses, we try to target around 21% to 22% of revenue and we're tracking around that level now. And we feel like there's a huge opportunity for us to continue invest in new areas of the business, like the actions genre where we haven't competed historically. It's a very ripe opportunity for us and we've been able to bring great talent in to try to build-out that part of the business. Our new mobile area with new studios coming on has also been important for us and we'll continue to invest there. And then last, but not least, continuing to build-out the platform in which we operate all our games on and we're trying to leverage through that network, we'll continue to be a key part of our investment. So you probably see that rough level as a percentage of sales be the focus going forward, which is a combination of the R&D level around 21 to 22, marketing in the 12 to 13 and G&A in the 7% to 8% range.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then one question for Andrew perhaps, some of your competitors have talked about plans or initiatives around the advertising and their mobile titles. Is that something that's contemplated in your 2017 guidance? And can you talk about any targe
componenttext: Got it. And then one question for Andrew perhaps, some of your competitors have talked about plans or initiatives around the advertising and their mobile titles. Is that something that's contemplated in your 2017 guidance? And can you talk about any targeted advertising you're doing or like to do in some of your sports titles going forward?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's again a great question. [indiscernible] advertising is certainly an important part of our business both now and going forward. We have been -- we have ads in both in our console games and our mobile games for some years and that business has con
componenttext: Yes, it's again a great question. [indiscernible] advertising is certainly an important part of our business both now and going forward. We have been -- we have ads in both in our console games and our mobile games for some years and that business has continued to grow. We often walk the fine line between maintaining the integrity of the experience with the provision of advertising inside those experiences. Right now, we have ad technology that we are implementing in some of our key mobile titles that is very targeted in nature and we believe is additive to the overall experience in the long-term. And players have been responding positively to that. So there's some advertising in FY '17 number. I would expect that as our network continues to grow beyond the hundreds of millions that we have today, that it will become a more meaningful part of our business in the future.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. One thing to remember there particularly for us is that, there's the ability to sell advertising but maybe equally or more important is the ability to cross promote to players to keep them in your network. And as we have a broader and broader portfol
componenttext: Yes. One thing to remember there particularly for us is that, there's the ability to sell advertising but maybe equally or more important is the ability to cross promote to players to keep them in your network. And as we have a broader and broader portfolio of games, particularly in mobile, that cross promotion advertising is very valuable to us. If you're holding on to a player in your network is very powerful, and so you'll see that type of advertising, which maybe less obvious to the average user than a traditional advert that you might see in the game.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Ben Schachter of Macquarie Research.
componenttext: Your next question is from Ben Schachter of Macquarie Research.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the full game downloads, anything you guys like to do to try to increase the discounts or the promotions or are you pretty happy to see it grow organically? And then if you're already over 30%, where do you think that number will be in FY '17 and in th
componenttext: On the full game downloads, anything you guys like to do to try to increase the discounts or the promotions or are you pretty happy to see it grow organically? And then if you're already over 30%, where do you think that number will be in FY '17 and in the next few years? And separately on Battlefield 1, any notable increases in the monetization or will be continued more maps and those kinds of things?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let me take the first one and then I'll have Andrew talk a little bit about Battlefield. It's a difficult prediction, right? We know that PCs took about 8 years to go from 0 to 75% full game downloads. But there's a lot of differences between the PC bu
componenttext: So let me take the first one and then I'll have Andrew talk a little bit about Battlefield. It's a difficult prediction, right? We know that PCs took about 8 years to go from 0 to 75% full game downloads. But there's a lot of differences between the PC business and the console business. We do know that the consumer is very interested in convenience, and we want to have product wherever the consumer want to shop, be it at retail store or a console. We, obviously, have great partners in retail and want to continue to have great partners over time and so we'll support them with great in-store merchandise and training and support. But at the same time, try to help educate our console partners as well on how to best market the products digitally. Our best guess today is that growth continues at about the pace that it has over last couple of years since the Gen4 consoles were rolled out. So could we see another 5% pop, meaning going from say high the 20s to the mid-30s? We do think that's possible. I think the big issues remain bandwidth, they remain cashless transactions, many of our customers may not have a credit card and they need a cashless transaction method to be able to play digitally, as well as, obviously, the residual value that some game retailers provide. All of those things are changing over time and we see that will continue to help support growth of full game downloads. But we want to allow the consumer to decide, we'll give them opportunities to buy certain things digitally that the may not be able to buy physically, especially digital-only offers. But at the end of the day, we really want to make sure we're allowing the consumer to buy the product wherever the consumer wishes to do that and we want to make sure we're there.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: As it relates to Battlefield 1 and extra monetization opportunity, taking a step back, any time we think about extra monetization inside experience, we really think about 2 vectors. One, are we able to provide value to the gamer in terms of extending and
componenttext: As it relates to Battlefield 1 and extra monetization opportunity, taking a step back, any time we think about extra monetization inside experience, we really think about 2 vectors. One, are we able to provide value to the gamer in terms of extending and enhancing their experience? And 2, are we able to do that in a world where we give them choice? Whenever one will be in a place where there's a belief that we are providing a pay-to-win mechanic inside of one of our games. I think what you've seen from us over the last couple of years is our ability to balance and deliver tremendous value through choice to our player, which is why our extra content line of business has continued to grow healthy. As we look at FY '17, we are forecasting again continued growth in that category. Given that in Battlefield 1, you will see both macro monetization opportunities from us, large maps and large-scale content, as well as micro monetization opportunities, smaller increments of gameplay. And then over time, what you'll see from us is elements of gameplay that allow gamers to engage and drive and extent their experience much the way people do with FIFA Ultimate Team and Madden Ultimate Team today. And we feel very confident in our ability to deliver that in a way that is deemed valuable by our player and drive increasing engagement over time with them.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can I squeeze one more in? [indiscernible] on the Analyst Day too much, but what are the key areas that you want to spend more time on with investors?
componenttext: Can I squeeze one more in? [indiscernible] on the Analyst Day too much, but what are the key areas that you want to spend more time on with investors?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think again we have been undergoing a fairly fundamental transformation of our business in the last few years. We feel like we're in a very, very strong place, we feel like we have a strong and predictable revenue source and the company's operating very
componenttext: I think again we have been undergoing a fairly fundamental transformation of our business in the last few years. We feel like we're in a very, very strong place, we feel like we have a strong and predictable revenue source and the company's operating very well right now. The management teams are doing great things in a world where our industry continues to grow. And we wanted to take the opportunity to share our vision for the future, how we see the industry growing, where we think the vectors for growth exist in that industry and how we believe Electronic Arts is uniquely well-positioned to benefit from those vectors of growth in the years ahead.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: And, Ben, I think part of that the goal is to make sure we're giving both the sales side and the buy-side exposure to the broader management team. And the chance to see the depth of what we've developed here as we feel very confident and we're excited to
componenttext: And, Ben, I think part of that the goal is to make sure we're giving both the sales side and the buy-side exposure to the broader management team. And the chance to see the depth of what we've developed here as we feel very confident and we're excited to make sure we showcase of that next week.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Mike Hickey with The Benchmark Company.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Mike Hickey with The Benchmark Company.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, you give the 25 million units growth for, I think, calendar year '16. I'm curious if your assumption, if you're expecting ease of new console this year, any price cuts of existing hardware or maybe other key considerations to that estimate. And then
componenttext: Mike, you give the 25 million units growth for, I think, calendar year '16. I'm curious if your assumption, if you're expecting ease of new console this year, any price cuts of existing hardware or maybe other key considerations to that estimate. And then I realized, obviously, you can't announce any hardware plans from your partners, but sort of why the speculation that you have kind of a mid-cycle upgrade coming? And I was curious if you could sort of shape for us why a midcycle upgrade could be positive for the industry? And also if there's any potential development expense to developing games in 4K?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I can't tell you a lot about what Microsoft or Sony's or other console makers plans are. But I think we've all seen some of the discounting that's been going on in the industry, both through the holidays and post-holidays. And there's continu
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I can't tell you a lot about what Microsoft or Sony's or other console makers plans are. But I think we've all seen some of the discounting that's been going on in the industry, both through the holidays and post-holidays. And there's continued aggressive bundling across the industry and I think all of that continue to drive people into consoles. I think the other thing that's important to remember is, there are very few Gen3 titles being still made, most of new titles that we're talking about, as well as the industry's talking, about are Gen4 only. And that is -- will clearly start to push people to ultimately buy a new console if they resisted because they've had a choice to play game on either Gen3 or Gen4. In terms of any midcycle upgrades once again, I can't predict. But what I can tell you is that, what we've heard publicly from the console makers is they're realizing that the compatibility issue across consoles is an important consumer issue. And as Microsoft shown they've tried to do with some backward compatibility on to older titles and new titles. I think that's going to be an important part of what a midcycle might look like if there is one, which removes a lot of the risk associated with what we've said historically with console cycles. We don't spend a lot of time worrying about it because we see like our ability to develop for whatever new technology comes, the risk of that is minimized because we've moved towards one single engine Frostbite. And we were's able to port that to whatever platform or point that to whatever platform is evolving or is upgraded. In addition, our business model is so much more diverse now than it has been historically, that notion of a console cycle becomes somewhat irrelevant in our ability to generate strong earnings and cash flow. So we'll all be interested to see where Microsoft and Sony come out if they do something sometime in the year to come. But we are excited about the continued growth of the business are not afraid of the cycle change if that was still to occur.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from Neil Doshi for Mizuho Securities.
componenttext: Your next question is from Neil Doshi for Mizuho Securities.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, on mobile, we've seen couple of quarters a very strong mid-teens year-over-year growth. Is the plan there really to focus around the core AAA titles and develop mobile ecosystem around those games? Or can we see some original IP on the mobile front
componenttext: First, on mobile, we've seen couple of quarters a very strong mid-teens year-over-year growth. Is the plan there really to focus around the core AAA titles and develop mobile ecosystem around those games? Or can we see some original IP on the mobile front? And then secondly, with the fairly healthy cash balance, how do you think about M&A as another way of kind of putting that cash to use?

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As it relates to a mobile, again when you have the benefit of the depth and breadth of our portfolio of great brands and IP, in a world where discovery is becoming challenged and the mobile market is increasingly forward competition, utilization of t
componenttext: Yes. As it relates to a mobile, again when you have the benefit of the depth and breadth of our portfolio of great brands and IP, in a world where discovery is becoming challenged and the mobile market is increasingly forward competition, utilization of those brand is certainly a great strength for us. And as you heard out in our prepared comments, we have the most installs of any publisher in calendar year 2015. And a lot of that is driven around the recognition of our brand and our IP and the quality of the experience that comes as part of those brands. As we look forward, certainly you'll see more great from us that are based around the depth and breadth of our IP portfolio, but at the same time, like in our console business in our PC business, we also look at opportunities to develop new IP in the space. And so you'd expect from us in the future a balanced approach to the marketplace, but certainly, we're not turning our back on our existing portfolio.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. In terms of M&A, I think over the last 3 years, we've gone through quite a transformation as a company. And 3 years ago, we could not have talked about M&A without having most of you throw something at us. And we feel like we've now at least earned t
componenttext:
Yes. In terms of M&A, I think over the last 3 years, we've gone through quite a transformation as a company. And 3 years ago, we could not have talked about M&A without having most of you throw something at us. And we feel like we've now at least earned the right to talk about it. The reality is there's not a lot of things out there to buy, this is an industry that's fairly consolidated already. We look at everything that is -- that's being considered to be sold out there or shopped. Most of them either we're not interested in or at a price that doesn't make sense to us to create value for shareholders. But we'll continue to do that, we'll continue to look for ways to bring in new talent and new properties over time if those are an opportunity. But we're certainly listening, probably more than we did 3 years ago and we're well aware of the opportunities out there and we'll continue to look at them.
That I think we're wrapped up. So I want to thank everyone and we'll see people here next week for earnings -- or for our Analyst Day. And if not, we hope to see you at EA Play in June. Thanks for your time.

headline: Electronic Arts Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, May 10, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you.
